Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: PoLS Student Research Network
Award.AbstractNarration: This collaborative award will support formation of a Physics of Living Systems Graduate Student Research Network, a trans-institutional community-based network of graduate students and graduate student educators all working on the physics of living systems. The initial participating institutions are the University of California, San Diego (which will coordinate the program), the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, Princeton University, Yale University, Cambridge University, and University College, London. The network structure will allow students at participating institutions (and a select number of other students) to meet their peers (both in-person and in-silico) and collectively help define the research agenda for this field. It will also allow for the creation of visiting internships, which will serve both as a way of broadening students perspectives on possible approaches to difficult research topics and as a way of creating collaborative ties between groups at the various sites. This structure will also enable the exploration of various means of educating these students in biology, while also ensuring that they develop and maintain a firm grounding in physics. This award is supported by the Physics of Livings Systems Program in the Physics Division in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences, as well as Molecular and Cellular Biosciences in the Directorate for Biological Sciences, and the Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PoLS Graduate Student Research Network (PoLS SRN) grant helped to create a trans-institutional network of graduate students and graduate student educators all working on the physics of living systems. Researchers in the network used both theoretical and experimental physics to further the understanding of biology and biomedicine.

Applying physics to living systems has become one of the growth areas for 21st century science. A key component that will ensure the continuing scientific vitality of this endeavor is the creation of students whose research training enables them to function comfortably at the boundaries of traditional disciplines. The network that the PoLS:SRN has created ensures the proper training of the next generation of PoLS scientists, and, more immediately, glued together existing research communities, inspiring collaborations which lead to significant progress on topics ranging from single molecule biophysics and systems biology to genetics and evolution.

The PoLS:SRN allowed students at participating institutions to meet their peers and collectively helped to define the research agenda for this field. In particular, the annual PoLS SRN meetings, where students presented their research and participated in workshops, was held in successive years at UCSD, Yale, Princeton, Munich, and Washington, DC. The PoLS SRN also facilitated visits among institutions – for both research and teaching – which broadened students’ perspectives on a variety of research topics and also facilitated new collaborations between not only students, but also more senior researchers. Regular contacts between network participants allowed the researchers involved to share insights gained and the resources developed to further graduate education in the physics of living systems.

The excitement surrounding the application of physics to problems in biology and medicine is a natural draw for increasing the diversity of the physics research community. The participation of females and underrepresented minorities (URMs) in interdisciplinary research and in the PoLS SRN at Yale – at both the student and faculty level – was and continues to be greater than it is in strictly disciplinary programs. In addition, the PoLS SRN program was directly coupled to a number of outreach programs at Yale, permitting PoLS SRN students to pass on their excitement about science to New Haven middle schoolers. In addition, Yale’s REU site summer program specifically targets URM students with an interest in research, and by providing a real exposure to a research environment, encourages these students to apply to pursue PoLS research in graduate school and a career in science.

More generally, creation of an interdisciplinary, trans-institutional and international network that embodies the broad benefits to students of being exposed to multiple viewpoints regarding difficult interdisciplinary research topics is applicable to a wide variety of other areas. The PoLS network paradigm and its mix of traditional meetings, internships and web-based encounters, served as an exemplar model for other communities faced with similar challenges.
